S1.E1.table: 𝐘(k)=𝐗𝐖(k)⁢𝐇+𝐄(k),superscript𝐘𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝑘𝐖𝐇superscript𝐄𝑘\mathbf{Y}^{(k)}={\mathbf{X}^{(k)}_{\mathbf{W}}}\mathbf{H}+\mathbf{E}^{(k)},bold_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H + bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (1)
references:
In the simulation setting of MCAR, we started by generating 100 no-missing datasets with 2 modalities and 100 subjects. Modality 1 has 1,000 voxels and modality 2 has 3,000 voxels. The number of true independent components is 2.
Data in each modality k=1,2𝑘12k=1,2italic_k = 1 , 2 can be generated using the LICA model in (1). We let 𝐖(k)=𝐈2superscript𝐖𝑘subscript𝐈2\mathbf{W}^{(k)}=\mathbf{I}_{2}bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and 𝐗𝐖(k)subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝑘𝐖\mathbf{X}^{(k)}_{\mathbf{W}}bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was reduced to 𝐗(k)superscript𝐗𝑘\mathbf{X}^{(k)}bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To generate 𝐗voxel×2(k)subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝑘voxel2\mathbf{X}^{(k)}_{\text{voxel}\times 2}bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT voxel × 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with two uncorrelated components, we imposed a binary structure – we started by assigning 1 to the first 100 entries of component 1 and the 101 to 200 entries of component 2 and assigning 0 to the rest of entries, and then we added some random noises from N⁢(0,1)𝑁01N(0,1)italic_N ( 0 , 1 ) to all the entries (this generation process is also shown in Figure 3). In addition, we let each element in 𝐇∼N⁢(0,1)similar-to𝐇𝑁01\mathbf{H}\sim N(0,1)bold_H ∼ italic_N ( 0 , 1 ) and each element in 𝐄(1),𝐄(2)∼N⁢(0,1)similar-tosuperscript𝐄1superscript𝐄2𝑁01\mathbf{E}^{(1)},\mathbf{E}^{(2)}\sim N(0,1)bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_N ( 0 , 1 ).

Same as in the setting of MCAR, in this MAR setting, we again started with 100 no-missing datasets, each of which has 2 modalities (with 1,000 voxels and 3,000 voxels, respectively), 100 subjects, and 2 true components.
To mimic the mechanism of MAR, where missingness depends on observed variables, we additionally generated two covariates for each subject. One (i.e., C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) is a continuous variable strongly correlated with the first component of 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H (i.e., H1subscript𝐻1H_{1}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) with a correlation of 0.5. The other (i.e., C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) is a continuous variable mediumly correlated with the second component of 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H (i.e., H2subscript𝐻2H_{2}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) with a correlation of 0.3. That is, we generated C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, H1subscript𝐻1H_{1}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and H2subscript𝐻2H_{2}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from a multivariate normal distribution, with zero means, unit variances, and a correlation matrix
(100.500100.30.501000.301)matrix100.500100.30.501000.301\begin{pmatrix}1&0&0.5&0\\
0&1&0&0.3\\
0.5&0&1&0\\
0&0.3&0&1\end{pmatrix}( start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 0.5 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 0.3 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0.5 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 0.3 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ).
Then, 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H was generated by combining the standardized H1subscript𝐻1H_{1}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and H2subscript𝐻2H_{2}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., (H1⊤,H2⊤)⊤H_{1}^{\top},H_{2}^{\top})^{\top}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), to force it to follow N⁢(0,1)𝑁01N(0,1)italic_N ( 0 , 1 ).
Again, data in each modality k𝑘kitalic_k was generated based on model (1), with 𝐖(k)=𝐈2superscript𝐖𝑘subscript𝐈2\mathbf{W}^{(k)}=\mathbf{I}_{2}bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and uncorrelated 𝐗voxel×2(k)subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝑘voxel2\mathbf{X}^{(k)}_{\text{voxel}\times 2}bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT voxel × 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated as shown in Figure 3, and elements in 𝐄(1),𝐄(2)∼N⁢(0,1)similar-tosuperscript𝐄1superscript𝐄2𝑁01\mathbf{E}^{(1)},\mathbf{E}^{(2)}\sim N(0,1)bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_N ( 0 , 1 ).

Same as in simulation settings 1 and 2, we started by generating 100 no-missing datasets, each of which has 2 modalities (with 1,000 voxels and 3,000 voxels, respectively), 100 subjects, and 2 true components.
Similar to the simulation setting 2, we generated two covariates (C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) that are related to 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H. We let C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a continuous variable correlated with the first component of 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H (i.e., H1subscript𝐻1H_{1}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).
However, the difference is that now we let C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a binary variable, rather than a continuous variable, related to the second component of 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H (i.e., H2subscript𝐻2H_{2}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Specifically, C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and H1subscript𝐻1H_{1}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were generated from a bivariate normal distribution, with zero means, unit variance, and a correlation of 0.5. C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was generated from the Bernoulli distribution with a probability of 0.5, and H2subscript𝐻2H_{2}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was generated by multiplying C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by 0.5 and adding some random noises from the standard normal distribution. Then, 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H was generated by combining the standardized H1subscript𝐻1H_{1}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and H2subscript𝐻2H_{2}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., (H1⊤,H2⊤)⊤H_{1}^{\top},H_{2}^{\top})^{\top}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).
Again, data in each modality k𝑘kitalic_k was generated based on model (1), with 𝐖(k)=𝐈2superscript𝐖𝑘subscript𝐈2\mathbf{W}^{(k)}=\mathbf{I}_{2}bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and uncorrelated 𝐗voxel×2(k)subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝑘voxel2\mathbf{X}^{(k)}_{\text{voxel}\times 2}bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT voxel × 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated as shown in Figure 3, and elements in 𝐄(1),𝐄(2)∼N⁢(0,1)similar-tosuperscript𝐄1superscript𝐄2𝑁01\mathbf{E}^{(1)},\mathbf{E}^{(2)}\sim N(0,1)bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_N ( 0 , 1 ).
Missing datasets were generated in the same way as in the simulation setting 2.

S2.T1.29.29.caption: Table 1: FI-LICA Algorithm Summary
references: We proposed a Full Information Linked ICA algorithm (FI-LICA) to deal with the missing data problem in multimodal fusion under the LICA framework. Our method is built upon the complete cases and incorporates all the available information to recover the missing latent information. Our algorithm is summarized in Table 1, with an illustrative diagram of two modalities in Figure 2. Details are described below.

S2.Ex1.table: 𝐘(k)=𝐗𝐖(k)⁢𝐇+𝐄(k)=(𝐗𝐖(k)⁢𝐃−1)⁢(𝐃𝐇)+𝐄(k)=𝐗𝐖(k)rescaled⁢𝐇rescaled+𝐄(k)superscript𝐘𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝑘𝐖𝐇superscript𝐄𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝑘𝐖superscript𝐃1𝐃𝐇superscript𝐄𝑘subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐗𝑘𝐖rescaledsubscript𝐇rescaledsuperscript𝐄𝑘\mathbf{Y}^{(k)}={\mathbf{X}^{(k)}_{\mathbf{W}}}{\mathbf{H}}+\mathbf{E}^{(k)}=% ({\mathbf{X}^{(k)}_{\mathbf{W}}}\mathbf{D}^{-1})\ (\mathbf{D}{\mathbf{H}})+% \mathbf{E}^{(k)}={\mathbf{X}^{(k)}_{\mathbf{W}}}_{\text{rescaled}}\mathbf{H}_{% \text{rescaled}}+\mathbf{E}^{(k)}bold_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H + bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( bold_DH ) + bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT rescaled end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT rescaled end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

S4.T2.1.caption: Table 2: Participants’ characteristics at baseline (ADNI Dataset)
references:
This analysis used three modalities – T1, AV45 PET, and FDG PET. Each PET modality was matched with one T1 data within one year of its scan date. Data with the earliest available PET scan was considered as baseline. We focused on 1291 subjects who had no missing in T1 but may have missing data in AV45 PET or FDG PET at baseline. We noticed that the two PET modalities might be matched with different T1 scans. To ensure that each subject had only one baseline measure, we took the earlier T1 data if the two T1 dates were within 6 months of each other, and if the two T1 dates were more than 6 months apart, we took the earlier T1 data along with its matched PET data and excluded the other pair of matched T1 and PET data. The Venn diagram of the sample size within the three modalities is displayed in Figure 1.
Participants’ characteristics are provided in Table 2.

S4.T3.1.caption: Table 3: Results of AUC and C-index from the data analysis (penalize all)
references:
In the classification analysis of CN and AD participants, for each of the three methods, we fitted the penalized logistic regression with 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H (40 subject scores) as well as gender and age at the scan.
10-fold cross-validation was used to determine the optimal model. Note that both FI-LICA and replace0 used full sample size whereas complete case analysis used those available in all three modalities. For fair comparison among the three methods, we also ran FI-LICA and replace0 using the complete cases only. Results of the AUC with its standard error (SE) are presented in Table 3.

In the analysis of predicting AD transition for MCI participants, for each of the three methods, we fitted the penalized Cox proportional hazards model with 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H}bold_H (40 subject scores) as well as gender and age at the scan.
10-fold cross-validation was used to determine the optimal model. Again, for fair comparison among the three methods, we ran FI-LICA and replace0 using the complete cases only. Results of the C-index with its standard error (SE) are presented in Table 3.
